A Learning-Based Attack Framework to Break SOTA Poisoning Defenses in Federated Learning

YuxinÂ Yang QiangÂ Li ChenfeiÂ Nie YuanÂ Hong MengÂ Pang and BinghuiÂ Wang Yuxin Yang is with the College of Computer Science and Technology, Jilin University, China, and Department of Computer Science, Illinois Institute of Technology, USA. Qiang Li and Chenfei Nie are with the College of Computer Science and Technology, Jilin University, China. Yuan Hong is with the School of Computing at University of Connecticut, USA. Meng Pang is with the School of Mathematics and Computer Sciences, Nanchang University, China. Binghui Wang is with the Department of Computer Science, Illinois Institute of Technology, USA. Wang is the corresponding author (bwang70@iit.edu).
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a novel client-server distributed learning framework that can protect data privacy. However, recent works show that FL is vulnerable to poisoning attacks. Many defenses with robust aggregators (AGRs) are proposed to mitigate the issue, but they are all broken by advanced attacks. Very recently, some renewed robust AGRs are designed, typically with novel clipping or/and filtering strategies, and they show promising defense performance against the advanced poisoning attacks. In this paper, we show that these novel robust AGRs are also vulnerable to carefully designed poisoning attacks. Specifically, we observe that breaking these robust AGRs reduces to bypassing the clipping or/and filtering of malicious clients, and propose an optimization-based attack framework to leverage this observation. Under the framework, we then design the customized attack against each robust AGR. Extensive experiments on multiple datasets and threat models verify our proposed optimization-based attack can break the SOTA AGRs. We hence call for novel defenses against poisoning attacks to FL. Code is available at: https://github.com/Yuxin104/BreakSTOAPoisoningDefenses.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Poisoning Attacks, Robust Aggregation.

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) [26, 36, 21, 47], a novel client-server distributed learning paradigm, allows participating clients keep and train their data locally and only share the trained local models (e.g., gradients), instead of the raw data, with a center server for aggregation. The aggregated local models forms a shared global model, which is used by clients for their main task. FL thus has been a great potential to protect data privacy and is widely applied to medical [37], financial [22], and other privacy-sensitive applications such as on-client item rankingÂ [26], content suggestions for on-device keyboardsÂ [8], and next word predictionÂ [24]. However, recent works show that the invisibility of client data also renders FL vulnerable to poisoning attacksÂ [5, 6, 15, 35, 34, 4, 41, 44, 51, 49], which aim to manipulate the training phase (and testing phase) of FL to disrupt the global model behavior or/and degrade the FL performance.

To defend against the poisoning attacks to FL, numerous robust aggregation algorithms (AGRs) [7, 14, 17, 48, 45, 13, 23, 32, 46, 27, 42, 11, 33, 29] have been proposed, where the key idea is to design a robust aggregator that aims to filter malicious gradients, i.e., those largely deviate from others. For instance, the Krum AGR [7] selects the gradient that is closest to its nâˆ’fâˆ’2ğ‘›ğ‘“2n-f-2 neighboring gradients measured by Euclidean distance, in order to filter fğ‘“f malicious gradients and nğ‘›n is the total number of clients. However, these AGRs are all broken by an advanced attack [35]. To further address the issue, some renewed AGRs equipped with an enhanced defense ability are proposed, which include FLAME [28], MDAM [16], FLDetector [50] and Centered Clipping (CC) [19] (or its variant Bucketing [20] to handle non-IID data). These new robust AGRs have shown effective defense performance against the advanced poisoning attack.

In this paper, however, we demonstrate that all these SOTA AGRs are still vulnerable to carefully designed (untargeted and targeted) poisoning attacks. Specifically, we first scrutinize these AGRs and find that they adopt either a novel clipping (e.g., in CC) or filtering (e.g., in MDAM and FLDetector), or the both (e.g., in FLAME) to remove the effect caused by malicious clients. Breaking these robust AGRs hence reduces to making malicious clients bypassing the clipping or/and filtering (See Figure 1). We then formalize this observation and design an optimization-based attack framework. To be specific, we first analyze the inherent attack objective and constraint within different AGRs and threat models. Then we instantiate this framework by: 1) adjusting the initial malicious gradients for targeted poisoning attacks to adhere to the constraint, and 2) constructing malicious gradients from benign ones for untargeted poisoning attacks to satisfy this constraint, thereby evading the filtering and clipping mechanisms. Finally, we propose an efficient solution for the optimization problem111We emphasize that our attack framework differs with [35] and extends it in two key aspects. First, the AGRs under consideration are more recent and robust than those considered in [35]. That is, all AGRs successfully broken by [35] can be also broken by our framework, while the opposite is not true. Second, our framework encompasses both targeted and untargeted attacks on robust AGRs, while [35] only focuses on untargeted attacks. Note that the generalization on targeted attacks is non-trivial. For instance, we test that the untargeted poisoning attack based on [35] completely fails to break FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector, while our designed targeted poisoning attacks can be successful (see Table II, Table III, and Table IV)..

We extensively investigate the effectiveness of our attack framework against the SOTA robust AGRs under multiple experimental settings and datasets. Our empirical evaluations show that our proposed poisoning attacks vigorously disrupt these robust AGRs. Below, we summarize the main contributions as follows:

  • â€¢

    We show that state-of-the-art AGRs can still be broken by advanced attacks.

  • â€¢

    We propose an optimization-based attack framework that explores both targeted and untargeted poisoning attacks against SOTA defenses under diverse scenarios.

  • â€¢

    We validate the effectiveness of our attacks on multiple experimental settings and datasets.

II Preliminaries

II-A Federated Learning (FL)

FL links a set of (e.g., nğ‘›n) clients and a server to collaboratively and iteratively train a shared global model over private client data, where the data across clients may be non independently and identically distributed (non-IID). II-B SOTA Robust Aggregators for FL

In this section, we will review the four SOTA robust AGRs for FL against poisoning attacks. The detailed implementations of these AGRs are shown in AlgorithmsÂ 2-6 in AppendixÂ VIII.

FLAMEÂ [28]. It is a defense against targeted poisoning attacks, particularly backdoor attacks. FLAME is based on the intuition that malicious gradients tend to deviate from the benign ones in length and/or angle. To limit the impact of backdoored models, FLAME proposes a two-stage solution in each tğ‘¡t-th round. First, it clips the client gradient with length larger than a clipping threshold qtsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡q^{t}, i.e., ğ itâ†qtâ€–ğ itâ€–2â€‹ğ itâ†superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}\leftarrow\frac{q^{t}}{\|\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}\|_{2}}\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}, if â€–ğ itâ€–2>qt,âˆ€isubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘¡2superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡for-allğ‘–\|\mathbf{g}_{i}^{t}\|_{2}>q^{t},\forall i. FLAME chooses qtsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡q^{t} as qt=MEDIANâ€‹(â€–ğ 1â€–2t,â€¦,â€–ğ nâ€–2t)superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡MEDIANsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ 12ğ‘¡â€¦superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘›2ğ‘¡q^{t}=\textrm{MEDIAN}(\|\mathbf{g}_{1}\|_{2}^{t},...,\|\mathbf{g}_{n}\|_{2}^{t}). Second, it inputs the clipped gradients and utilizes a dynamic clustering technique HDBSCAN [10] to further filter out gradients with high angular deviations from the majority gradients. Specifically, HDBSCAN clusters the clients based on the density of cosine distance distribution on gradient pairs and dynamically determines the number of clusters. By assuming an upper bounded (<n/2absentğ‘›2<n/2) number of malicious clients, FLAME sets the minimum size of the largest cluster to be n/2+1ğ‘›21{n}/{2}+1 to ensure that the resulting cluster only contains benign clients. With the clipping and filtering, FLAME finally only averages the gradients of clients in the benign cluster to update the global model.

MDAMÂ [16]. It proposes to use distributed momentum into existing aggregators (e.g., Krum, Median, TM, MDA) to enhance the robustness against poisoning attacks, and provably shows that MDA under distributed momentum (MDAM) obtains the best defense performance. III Threat Model

In this section, we discuss the threat model of attacking the SOTA robust AGRs, i.e., targeted poisoning attacks to FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector, and untargeted poisoning attacks to CC and CC-B. Note here that the targeted attack mainly refers backdoor attacks.

Adversaryâ€™s Objective. For targeted poisoning attacks, an adversary aims to optimize the existing malicious gradients obtained by backdoor poisoning to evade filtering or/and clipping of the robust AGR (e.g., FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector), so that the resulting global model can achieve a high level on both the main task accuracy and backdoor accuracy. For untargeted poisoning attacks, the adversaryâ€™s goal is to craft malicious gradients based on benign gradients to disrupt the serverâ€™s robust aggregation (e.g., via CC and CC with Bucketing), consequently diminishing the overall main task accuracy of the global model.

Adversaryâ€™s Capability. We assume the total number of malicious clients is f<n/2ğ‘“ğ‘›2f<n/2. All malicious clients can collude with each other and have indexes within [f]delimited-[]ğ‘“[f], i.e., from 1 to fğ‘“f, without loss of generality. For untargeted poisoning attacks, a malicious client can carefully modify its normally trained gradient to be a malicious one such that it can fool the robust AGR. For targeted backdoor attacks, we assume the adversary uses the strong model replacement attackÂ [4], where it aims to replace the true global model ğ°t+1=ğ°t+Î·nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ itsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡1superscriptğ°ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘–{\bf w}^{t+1}={\bf w}^{t}+\frac{\eta}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{g}^{t}_{i} with any model ğ±ğ±{\bf x} by poisoning the gradients ğ iâˆˆ[f]tsubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{t}_{i\in[f]}. In our scenario, we extend the model replacement attack from 1 to fğ‘“f malicious clients. Specifically, the fğ‘“f poisoned client gradients, denoted as ğ iâˆˆ[f]psubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]}222For notation simplicity, we will omit the round tğ‘¡t in the gradients ğ itsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bf g}_{i}^{t}, and the meaning is clear from context. to differentiate with the benign gradients ğ jâˆˆ[f+1,n]subscriptğ ğ‘—ğ‘“1ğ‘›{\bf g}_{j\in[f+1,n]}, has the relationship: âˆ‘i=1fğ ip=nÎ·â€‹(ğ±âˆ’ğ°t)âˆ’âˆ‘j=f+1nğ jsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğœ‚ğ±superscriptğ°ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘“1ğ‘›subscriptğ ğ‘—\sum_{i=1}^{f}\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}=\frac{n}{\eta}({\bf x}-{\bf w}^{t})-\sum_{j=f+1}^{n}\mathbf{g}_{j}. As the global model converges, each local model may be close enough to the global model such that the benign gradients start to cancel out, i.e., âˆ‘j=f+1nğ j=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘“1ğ‘›subscriptğ ğ‘—0\sum_{j=f+1}^{n}\mathbf{g}_{j}=0Â [4]. Hence, we have âˆ‘i=1fğ ipâ‰ˆnÎ·â€‹(ğ±âˆ’ğ°t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğœ‚ğ±superscriptğ°ğ‘¡\sum_{i=1}^{f}\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}\approx\frac{n}{\eta}({\bf x}-{\bf w}^{t}). Then an adversary can simply solve for the poisoned gradients of the malicious clients as: ğ ipâ‰ˆnfâ€‹Î·â€‹(ğ±âˆ’ğ°t),âˆ€iâˆˆ[f].formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘“ğœ‚ğ±superscriptğ°ğ‘¡for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}\approx\frac{n}{f\eta}({\bf x}-{\bf w}^{t}),\forall i\in[f].

Adversaryâ€™s Knowledge. We consider two dimensions: knowledge of the AGR aggregator and knowledge of the gradients shared by benign clients (see Table I). According to whether the adversary knows the AGR aggregator, we classify the malicious attacks into AGR-tailored and AGR-agnostic. Similarly, we also divide the attacks into gradients-known and gradients-unknown based on whether the adversary is aware of the benign clientsâ€™ gradients. Note that the adversary performing the gradients-unknown attack can utilize the clean data of the malicious clients to obtain benign gradients.

IV Optimization-Based Poisoning Attacks to SOTA Robust AGRs in FL

IV-A Overview

Recall that SOTA defenses against untargeted and targeted poisoning attacks all design robust AGRs that involve clipping or/and filtering malicious gradients based on their statistic differences with benign gradients. Hence, the main insight of our attack framework is to carefully create malicious gradients {ğ ic}iâˆˆ[f]subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\{\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i}\}_{i\in[f]} to evade these operations in SOTA AGRs. At a high-level, our objective function aims to create the malicious gradients {ğ ic}iâˆˆ[f]subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\{\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i}\}_{i\in[f]}(For ease of description, we also use ğ icsubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i} to indicate malicious momentum ğ¦icsubscriptsuperscriptğ¦ğ‘ğ‘–\mathbf{m}^{c}_{i}) such that their maximum distance from the benign gradients {ğ j}jâˆˆ[f+1,n]subscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘—ğ‘—ğ‘“1ğ‘›\{\mathbf{g}_{j}\}_{j\in[f+1,n]} is within a predefined/calculated threshold tâ€‹hğ‘¡â„th used by the filtering or/and clipping operation in SOTA AGRs. Next, we investigate the vulnerabilities of the SOTA robust AGRs (i.e., FLAME, MDAM, FLDetector, and CC (with Bucketing)) and then instantiate our attack framework in Equation (1) by designing optimization-based attacks against these AGRs one-by-one.

IV-B Targeted Poisoning Attack to FLAME, MDAM, FLDetector

AGR-Tailored Attack to FLAME. As stated in SectionÂ II-B, FLAME first limits the gradients with large length to not exceed a clipping threshold qtsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡q^{t} in each tğ‘¡t-th round. To attack this clipping, we deploy projected gradient descent (PGD) with the adversary periodically projecting their client gradients on a small ball centered around the global model ğ°tsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡{\bf w}^{t}. To be specific, the malicious client calculates qtsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡q^{t} so that the malicious gradients ğ iâˆˆ[f]psuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘\mathbf{g}_{i\in[f]}^{p} respect the constraint â€–ğ ipâ€–2â‰¤|qtâˆ’â€–ğ°tâ€–2|,âˆ€iâˆˆ[f]formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘2superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptnormsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡2for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\left\|\mathbf{g}_{i}^{p}\right\|_{2}\leq\left|q^{t}-\|{\bf w}^{t}\|_{2}\right|,\forall i\in[f], i.e., malicious gradients distribute over a ball with ğ°tsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡{\bf w}^{t} as the center and |qtâˆ’â€–ğ°tâ€–2|superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptnormsuperscriptğ°ğ‘¡2\left|q^{t}-\|{\bf w}^{t}\|_{2}\right| as the radius.

Additionally, FLAME uses pairwise cosine distances to measure the angular differences between all pairs of model gradients, and applies the HDBSCAN clustering algorithm to further filter the malicious gradients with large angular deviations. Hence, a successful attack also requires crafting the malicious gradients (denoted as ğ iâˆˆ[f]csubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]}) to evade the filtering. AGR-Agnostic Attacks (to FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector). It is challenging to design tailored attacks on FLDetector, due to it uses the history information in each round that is not easy to incorporate into the attack optimization. To relax it, we propose an AGR-agnostic attack formulation; and if the AGR-agnostic attack is already effective, then AGR-tailored attack can performance better. Specifically, in this setting, the adversary does not know which AGR the defense uses. To design effective AGR-agnostic attacks, we need to uncover the shared property in the existing robust AGRs. Particularly, we note that, though with different techniques, existing robust AGRs mainly perform statistical analysis on client models and identify malicious clients as those largely deviate from others based on some similarity metric such as Euclidean distance and cosine similarity. Based on this intuition, we hence propose to adjust the malicious gradients to be close to the benign ones such that these malicious gradients can be selected by (any) robust AGRs. W.l.o.g, we use Euclidean distance as the similarity metric and extend Equation (3) to a more general case. Specifically, we optimize ğ iâˆˆ[f]psubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]} to approach ğ bsuperscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}^{b} so that its maximum distance with respect to any benign gradient is upper bounded by the maximum distance between any two benign gradients. Formally, the equation can be expressed as follows:

Î³=argâ¡maxÎ³,iâˆˆ[f],jâˆˆ[f+1,n]â€‹â€–ğ icâˆ’ğ jâ€–2,ğ›¾formulae-sequenceğ›¾ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘—ğ‘“1ğ‘›subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ ğ‘—2\displaystyle\gamma=\underset{\gamma,i\in[f],j\in[f+1,n]}{\arg\max}\left\|\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i}-\mathbf{g}_{j}\right\|_{2}, (4)
s.t.âˆ¥ğ icâˆ’ğ jâˆ¥2â‰¤maxk,jâˆˆ[f+1,n]âˆ¥ğ kâˆ’ğ jâˆ¥2,\displaystyle s.t.\ \ \left\|\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i}-\mathbf{g}_{j}\right\|_{2}\leq\underset{k,j\in[f+1,n]}{\max}\ \left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}-\mathbf{g}_{j}\right\|_{2},
ğ ic=ğ ip+Î³â€‹(ğ bâˆ’ğ ip).subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–ğ›¾superscriptğ ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–\displaystyle\quad\ \ \ \mathbf{g}^{c}_{i}=\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}+\gamma(\mathbf{g}^{b}-\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}).

IV-C Untargeted Poisoning Attack to CC and CC with Bucketing

AGR-Tailored Attack to CC. CC clips each client gradient ğ isubscriptğ ğ‘–\mathbf{g}_{i} by ğ iâ€‹minâ¡(1,Ï„â€–ğ iâ€–2)subscriptğ ğ‘–1ğœsubscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘–2\mathbf{g}_{i}\min(1,\frac{\tau}{\left\|\mathbf{g}_{i}\right\|_{2}}) to reduce the negative effect caused by malicious gradients with a large length. However, we observe that clipping is ineffective if we can always maintain Ï„â€–ğ iâ€–2â‰¥1ğœsubscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘–21\frac{\tau}{\left\|\mathbf{g}_{i}\right\|_{2}}\geq 1, i.e., â€–ğ iâ€–2â‰¤Ï„subscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘–2ğœ\left\|\mathbf{g}_{i}\right\|_{2}\leq\tau. Under this, we can create the malicious gradients ğ iâˆˆ[f]csuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘\mathbf{g}_{i\in[f]}^{c} such that:

s.t.â€–ğ icâ€–2â‰¤Ï„,ğ ic=ğ b+Î³â€‹ğ ip,ğ ip=âˆ’signâ€‹(ğ b).formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘¡formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘2ğœformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘superscriptğ ğ‘ğ›¾subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–signsuperscriptğ ğ‘\displaystyle s.t.\left\|\mathbf{g}_{i}^{c}\right\|_{2}\leq\tau,\ \ \mathbf{g}_{i}^{c}=\mathbf{g}^{b}+\gamma{\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}},\ \ \mathbf{g}^{p}_{i}=-\textrm{sign}(\mathbf{g}^{b}).\

There are many ways to set malicious gradients ğ iâˆˆ[f]psubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]}. Motivated by [35], one simple yet effective way is setting ğ iâˆˆ[f]psubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]} as the inverse sign of the reference benign gradient ğ bsuperscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}^{b}, which can be a randomly chosen benign gradient.

AGR-Tailored Attack to CC-B. Our attack on CC with bucketing is similar to that on CC. As seen in SectionÂ II-B, bucketing is a post-processing step on client gradients mainly mitigating the non-IID data across clients. In principle, a successful attack on CC will render the bucketing aggregation ineffective as well. Here, we directly craft malicious gradients using Equation (5) and then perform CC aggregation with bucketing on the crafted malicious gradients.

AGR-Agnostic Attack (to CC and CC-B). Ï„ğœ\tau is the only hyperparameter in CC. In this attack setting, Ï„ğœ\tau is unknown to the adversary. To differentiate between Ï„ğœ\tau used in CC and that in the attack, we name it as CC-Ï„ğœ\tau and ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau, respectively. In practice, the used CC-Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™s often have a format of 10xsuperscript10ğ‘¥10^{x}. Hence the adversary can exploit these potential values as ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau to execute the attack in Equation (5). Note that there is no such limitation and our experimental results in Section V show a larger value of ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau always ensures the attack to be effective, whatever the true CC-Ï„ğœ\tau is.

IV-D Solving for The Scaling Hyperparameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma

IV-D1 Binary Search Algorithm

Both the targeted and untargeted poisoning attacks to FL involve optimizing the scaling hyperparameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma. For the untargeted attacks, the malicious gradients ğ iâˆˆ[f]csubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]} are obtained by maximizing Î³ğ›¾\gamma to render the attack ğ iâˆˆ[f]c=ğ b+Î³â€‹ğ iâˆˆ[f]psuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘superscriptğ ğ‘ğ›¾subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}_{i\in[f]}^{c}=\mathbf{g}^{b}+\gamma\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]} be effective. For the targeted attacks, in contrast, an adversary generates ğ iâˆˆ[f]csubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]} by exploring the minimum Î³ğ›¾\gamma to maintain the attack effectiveness, e.g., ğ iâˆˆ[f]c=ğ iâˆˆ[f]p+Î³â€‹(ğ bâˆ’ğ iâˆˆ[f]p)subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ›¾superscriptğ ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]}=\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]}+\gamma(\mathbf{g}^{b}-\mathbf{g}^{p}_{i\in[f]}). AlgorithmÂ 1 shows the details of solving Î³ğ›¾\gamma in the two scenarios. Specifically, we start with a small (or large) Î³ğ›¾\gamma for untargeted (or targeted) attacks and increase (or decrease) Î³ğ›¾\gamma with a step size step until ğ’ªğ’ª\mathcal{O} returns â€œTrueâ€, where ğ’ªğ’ª\mathcal{O} takes as input the union of the malicious and benign gradients, i.e., ğ iâˆˆ[n]=ğ iâˆˆ[f]câˆªğ {iâˆˆ[f+1,n]}subscriptğ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ ğ‘–ğ‘“1ğ‘›\mathbf{g}_{i\in[n]}=\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]}\cup\mathbf{g}_{\{i\in[f+1,n]\}}, and Î³ğ›¾\gamma, and outputs â€œTrueâ€ if the obtained ğ iâˆˆ[f]csubscriptsuperscriptğ ğ‘ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“\mathbf{g}^{c}_{i\in[f]} in Equations (2)-(5) satisfies the adversarial objective. We halve the step size for each Î³ğ›¾\gamma update to make the search finer.

Complexity Analysis. AlgorithmÂ 1 iteratively optimizes Î³ğ›¾\gamma to satisfy the condition ğ’ªâ€‹(ğ iâˆˆ[n],Î³)==ğ’ªsubscriptğ ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ›¾\mathcal{O}(\mathbf{g}_{i\in[n]},\gamma)== True. In each iteration, it verifies the adversarial objective in Equations (2)-(5), e.g., computes the pairwise gradient/momentum distance among benign clients, and that between malicious clients and benign clients and checks whether the inequality satisfies. The complexity per iteration is O((n2âˆ’f2)âˆ—#superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğ‘“2#(n^{2}-f^{2})*\#model parameters), where nğ‘›n and fğ‘“f are the total number of clients and malicious clients, respectively. On the other hand, AlgorithmÂ 1 guarantees to converge and stops when stepâ‰¤Îµstepğœ€\text{step}\leq\varepsilon. Note that step is initialized as Î³iâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹t/2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡2\gamma_{init}/2 and halved in each iteration. So the convergence iteration mğ‘šm is obtained when Î³iâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹t/2m+1â‰¤Îµsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡superscript2ğ‘š1ğœ€\gamma_{init}/2^{m+1}\leq\varepsilon, which means m=log2â¡(Î³iâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹t/Îµ)âˆ’1ğ‘šsubscript2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğœ€1m=\log_{2}(\gamma_{init}/\varepsilon)-1.

IV-D2 Analytic Solution

We notice that Î³ğ›¾\gamma can be computed directly with an analytic solution. Yet this approach incurs higher computational costs than our iterative solver. Particularly, the direct solver has a total complexity of 24âˆ—#24#24*\#model parameters, while our iterative solver has a complexity of 4âˆ—#4#4*\#model parameters per iterations. As the number of iterations (controlled by Î³iâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\gamma_{init} and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) is small (â‰¤5absent5\leq 5 in our experiments), the total complexity of our iterative solver is slightly smaller than the direct solver.

Complexity Analysis. Taking Equation (4) for instance, it can be rewritten as a quadratic inequation with one unknown variable Î³ğ›¾\gamma:

So the total complexity is 24â€‹d24ğ‘‘24d. In our attack, each iteration calculates LHS of Equation (6), which has complexity 4â€‹d4ğ‘‘4d. As the number of iterations (controlled by Î³iâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\gamma_{init} and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) is small (i.e., 4-5 in our experiments), the total complexity of our iterative attack is slightly smaller.

V Experiments

In this section, we evaluate our attack framework on the SOTA robust AGRs. We first set up the experiments and then show the attack results on each robust AGR.

V-A Experimental Setup

Datasets and Architectures. Following existing worksÂ [16, 19, 50, 31, 44], we consider FL on three benchmark image datasets, i.e., FMNIST, CIFAR10, and FEMNISTÂ [9], where the first two datasets are IID distributed, while the third one is non-IID distributed. FMNIST has 60K training images and 10K testing images from 10 classes with image size 28x28. CIFAR10 has 50K training images and 10K testing images. FEMNIST includes 3,383 clients, 62 classes, and a total of 805,263 grayscale images. For FL training, we selected 1,000 out of the 3,383 clients. For FMNIST and FEMNIST, we consider a convolutional neural network (CNN) with 2 convolutional (Conv) layers followed by 2 fully-connected (FC) layers. While for CIFAR10, we use a CNN with 3 Conv layers and 3 FC layers on the targeted attack, and a ResNet-20 [18] on the untargeted attack. We follow FLAME, MDAM, FLDetector, CC, CC-B to set the number of total clients and fraction of clients selected in each round. For instance, the total number of clients in CC is 50, and all clients are selected for training. We set the backdoor classes to 444 and 777 for targeted poisoning attacks, and use the cross entropy loss for federated training. We set the learning rate for serverâ€™s global aggregation as 1.01.01.0 and client training as 0.10.10.1 and total number of rounds is 200.

Parameter Setting. We set the ratio of malicious clients f/nğ‘“ğ‘›f/n to be {{\{2%, 5%, 10%, 20%}}\} for FLAME, CC, and CC-B, and {{\{5%, 10%, 20%, 30%}}\} for MDAM and FLDetector, consider their different defense performance. In each malicious client, we set the data poisoning rate as 50%percent5050\%, meaning 50% of the client data are poisoned. In MDAM, we consider momentum coefficients Î²={\beta=\{0, 0.6, 0.9, 0.99}}\}, where Î²=0ğ›½0\beta=0 means we do not use the momentum and it reduces to the standard MDA. In CC and CC-B, both the defense CC-Ï„ğœ\tau and attack ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau are set within {{\{0.1,1,10,100,1000}}\}. We also investigate the effect of Bucketing and set the number of buckets sğ‘ s in {{\{0,2,5,10}}\}, where s=0ğ‘ 0s=0 means we do not use buckets.

Evaluation Metric. For targeted backdoor poisoning attacks, we use both main task accuracy (MA) and backdoor accuracy (BA) as the evaluation metrics. An attack obtaining a larger MA and a larger BA indicates it is more effective. For untargeted poisoning attacks, the goal is to reduce the main task accuracy. Therefore, a smaller MA generally indicates better attack effectiveness.

V-B Our Attack Results on FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector

Comparing with a SOTA Targeted Attack. We choose the SOTA Distributed Backdoor Attack (DBA) to FL [44] as a baseline targeted poisoning attack for comparison. DBA decomposes a global trigger into several local triggers and embeds these local triggers separately into the training data of different malicious clients. Compared with the classic centralized backdoor that injects the global trigger, DBA is shown to be more persistent, stealthy, and effective (more details about DBA can be referred to [44]). To better show the attack effectiveness, our attack just uses the centralized backdoor, where we set the global trigger size to be the same as that in DBA. Following DBA, we use the rectangle pattern as the global trigger and DBA separates the global trigger into four local triggers. We also show the DBA performance with different number of local triggers and the results are very close (see TableÂ XV). The algorithm details of DBA and additional attack baselines are shown in AlgorithmsÂ 7-9 in AppendixÂ IX.

Results on Attacking FLAME. The experimental results on different threat models are shown in Table II. we have the following key observations: 1) DBA is ineffective against FLAME, while our attack is effective. DBA obtains BAs that are low. This shows FLAME can defend against DBA, which is also verified in [28]. In contrast, our attack achieves very high BAs, validating that it can break FLAME and our optimization-based attack is promising. 2) Our attack can better maintain the FL performance than DBA. Our attack obtains identical or better MAs than DBA and has closer MAs to those under no attack. This implies our attack does not affect the main task performance. 3) In general, our attack has better performance under a strong threat model than that under a weak threat model. Specifically, comparing AGR-tailored vs. AGR-agnostic and gradients-known vs. gradients-unknown, all the BAs obtained by our attack are larger, while with similar MAs. 4) Defending against attacks on non-IID datasets is more challenging than on IID datasets. We notice that the BAs on the non-IID FEMNIST are much larger than those on the IID FMNIST and CIFAR10. This is because the client models can be more diverse when trained on non-IID data, thus making it more difficult to differentiate between benign models and malicious models via similarity metrics. 5) More malicious clients yield better attack performance. Our attack can obtain larger BAs, with an increasing number of malicious clients. This is obvious, since more malicious clients have a larger space to perform the attack. We notice that 5%percent55\%-10%percent1010\% colluding malicious clients are sufficient to obtain a promising attack performance.

Results on Attacking MDAM. The detailed results are in TableÂ III where we set the momentum coefficient to be Î²=0.9ğ›½0.9\beta=0.9. The results on the impact of Î²ğ›½\beta are shown in TableÂ V. We have similar observations as those on attacking FLMAE. For instance, our attack achieves larger MAs and BAs than DBA, showing our attack is more effective than DBA. MDAM can completely defend against DBA on IID datasets when the fraction of malicious clients is small. Also, defending against attacks on non-IID dataset is more challenging. Similarly, all these results show that our optimization-based attack can evade the filtering strategy in MDAM.

Results on Attacking FLDetector. TableÂ IV shows the results of our (AGR-agnostic and gradient-unknown) attack on FLDetector. The results reveal FLDetector almost fails to defend against our attack under the least adversary knowledge. To understand the underlying reason, we show in FigureÂ 2 the computed suspicious scores by FLDetector for each client and in each FL round. We observe the suspicious scores are similar across all (malicious and benign) clients and FL rounds. Hence, it is challenging to use kğ‘˜k-means to detect malicious clients based on these suspicious scores.

V-C Our Attack Results on CC and CC-B

Comparing with SOTA Untargeted Attacks. We choose two SOTA untargeted poisoning attack methods, namely LIE [5] (AGR-agnostic) and Fang [15] (AGR-tailored), for comparison. Roughly speaking, LIE computes the average Î¼ğœ‡\mu and standard deviation Î´ğ›¿\delta of the benign gradients, and computes a coefficient zğ‘§z based on the total number of benign and malicious clients, and finally computes the malicious update as Î¼+zâ€‹Î´ğœ‡ğ‘§ğ›¿\mu+z\delta. Fang calculates the average Î¼ğœ‡\mu of benign gradients and introduces a perturbation ğ p=âˆ’superscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}^{p}=-sign(Î¼)ğœ‡(\mu). Ultimately, it computes a malicious update as ğ c=Î¼+Î³â€‹ğ psuperscriptğ ğ‘ğœ‡ğ›¾superscriptğ ğ‘\mathbf{g}^{c}=\mu+\gamma\mathbf{g}^{p}. The attack initiates a relatively large Î³ğ›¾\gamma and iteratively halves it until Î³ğ›¾\gamma yields promising attack performance. The algorithm details of LIE and Fang are in Algorithms 8-9 in AppendixÂ IX. Note that, different from targeted poisoning attacks, our goal in this attack setting is to achieve as small MAs as possible.

Results on Attacking CC. As stated in SectionÂ IV-C, CC has the only important parameter Ï„ğœ\tau. An AGR-tailored attack implies ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau set by the adversary equals to the true CC-Ï„ğœ\tau, while an AGR-agnostic attack means ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau and CC-Ï„ğœ\tau are different. TableÂ VI shows our attack results on IID FMNIST and CIFAR10 where we set CC-Ï„ğœ\tau=10 and try different ATK-Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™s. The attack results on other CC-Ï„ğœ\tauâ€™s are shown in TableÂ VII. We observe that: 1) Our attack, even in the gradients-unknown setting, is more effective than LIE and Fang with known gradients; 2) Our attack obtains small MAs when the adversary knows the true CC-Ï„ğœ\tau; 3) By setting ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau to be a larger value, e.g., 1000, our attack is always effective. This is because a larger ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau can always make the adversary easier to satisfy the adversary objective in Equation 5. Such results guide the adversary to set a relatively large Ï„ğœ\tau in practice.

Results on Attacking CC with Bucketing. Since the bucketing strategy is mainly to address the heterogeneous data issue across clients, we only evaluate our attack against CC-B on the non-IID FEMNIST. As shown in Table VI, our attack can significantly reduce the MAs especially when ATK-Ï„ğœ\tau is larger. This suggests our attack on non-IID datasets can also evade the aggregation of CC-B. We also explore the impact of the number of buckets sğ‘ s on our attack. As shown in Table VIII, the results show that our attack is insensitive to sğ‘ s.

V-D More Experimental Results

Impact of Training Rounds and Dataset Sizes. We explore the impact of varying number of training rounds and dataset sizes on our attacks in the default setting. Figure 3 and Table IX show the results on the two hyperparameters, respectively. We see the performance of most experiments (except FLAME) stabilizes after 100 rounds, and the proposed attacks are effective across different dataset sizes.

Comparison of Directly Solving for Î³ğ›¾\gamma. We also investigate the impact of the Î³ğ›¾\gamma solver. In these experiments, we evaluate our attacks by directly solving for Î³ğ›¾\gamma. The comparison results under â€œAGE-tailored + gradient knownâ€ and the default setting are presented in Table X. We observe both two types of solvers produce very similar attack performance. On average, we find the difference of the calculated Î³ğ›¾\gamma between our iterative solver and the direct solver is less than 5%, and the iterative solver is slightly faster (approximately 1.2Ã—1.2\times) than the direct solver.

More attack baselines. We test two more untarget attacks (sign flipping and label flipping attacks [15]) against CC(-B), and a targeted attack [41] against MDAM. The results under the default setting are shown in Table XI. We can see the SOTA robust FL can effectively defend against these attacks.

Comparison with class bias increase attack. We evaluate the class bias increase attack against FLAME, MDAM, and FLDetector with a 50% bias level, where we randomly misclassify 50% samples from not the target class (e.g., class 5) to the target class (e.g., class 7). The results in the default setting are shown in Table XII. We can see this attack fails to break SOTA AGRs, while our optimization-based attack successfully bypasses these defenses.

More defense baselines. We mainly focus on robust aggregation based poisoning defenses, since they achieved SOTA defense performance. Here, we also test a popular non-robust aggregation based backdoor defense BaFFLe [2] against our gradient-unknown attack, and the results are shown in Table XIII. We can see BaFFLe is not effective enough, i.e., our attack still has high backdoor accuracy.

Comparison with more AGRs used [35]. We compare our attack with the attack in [35] against the AGRs in [35] in the AGR-agnostic fashion. The results in the default setting are shown in Table XIV. We can see both attacks have similar performance, though our attack is not specially designed for AGRs in [35].

V-E Provable Defense Results against our Attack

In this experiment, we assess the effectiveness of the SOTA provable defense CRFL [43] (Algorithm 10 in AppendixÂ IX) against our (AGR-agnostic) targeted poisoning attack. The results are depicted in FigureÂ 4. The certified radius means the maximal (l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2}) norm of the trigger that can be injected to the clean data, such that the backdoored model still makes correct predictions; and the certified accuracy is the ratio of testing data under the given certified radius. We observe a notably small certified radius/accuracy in all datasets, and CRFL is unable to certify any testing data whose injected backdoor trigger is with an l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2} radius larger than 3.5â€‹eâˆ’33.5ğ‘’33.5e-3. These results reveal inherent challenges of CRFL to defend against our attacks, even in the AGR-agnostic setting.

More results for our attacks against CRFL. We investigate the impact of the total number of clients nğ‘›n and total training rounds on CRFL, while keeping other parameters the default values. The results are in Figure 5 and Figure 6, respectively. We can see the certified radius increases as nğ‘›n increases (this reduces the attack effect) and training rounds decrease (attack is less persistent).

VI Related Work

Poisoning Attacks to FL. Poisoning attacks can be classified as targeted and untargeted attacks based on the adversaryâ€™s goal. Targeted poisoning attacks to FLÂ [34, 4, 41, 44, 51] aim to misclassify the targeted inputs as the attacker desires, while maintaining the performance on clientsâ€™ clean inputs. For instance, backdoor attacks [4, 41, 44] are a subset of targeted attacks, where an adversary (e.g., malicious clients) injects a backdoor into the target inputs and tampers with their labels as the adversary desired label during training. During testing, the trained backdoored global model misclassifies any test input with the backdoor as the desired attack label, while correctly classifying the clean testing inputs. In contrast, untargeted poisoning attacksÂ [5, 6, 15, 35] aim to minimize the accuracy of the global model on test inputs, which can be implemented by data poisoning [39] or model poisoning [35, 15, 6]. For instance, [35] proposes an untargeted poisoning attack framework to mount optimal model poisoning attacks. Different from the existing attacks, we propose an attack framework that unifies both targeted and untargeted attacks to FL.

Defenses against Poisoning Attacks to FL. Existing (empirical) defenses focus on designing robust aggregators (AGRs) and they can be roughly classified as two categories: the ones that limit the attack effectiveness via clipping malicious gradientsÂ [19, 28, 48, 4, 29]; and the ones that weaken the contributions of malicious models by detecting and filtering themÂ [16, 33, 7, 45, 27, 2]. Well-known AGRs include (Multi-) KrumÂ [7], BulyanÂ [17], Trimmed-Mean (TM) Â [45, 48], MedianÂ [45, 48], Minimum Diameter Averaging (MDA)Â [32], Adaptive Federated Averaging (AFA)Â [27], and FLTrustÂ [11]. However, all these defenses are broken by the optimization-based adaptive (untargeted poisoning) attack proposed by [35].

To mitigate this attack, SOTA poisoning defenses incorporating novel robust AGRs have been proposed, where the representatives are CC [19], MDAM [16], FLAME [28], and FLDetector [50]333FedRecoverÂ [12] bases on FLDetector to first detect malicious clients and then recover the global model.. For instance, CC clips malicious gradients by a tunable threshold Ï„ğœ\tau (hyper-parameter), while FLAME sets the clipping threshold through computing the median value of the Euclidean distance between the global model and local models. In contrast, MDAM chooses a subset of nâˆ’fğ‘›ğ‘“n-f clients (where fğ‘“f is the total number of malicious clients) with the smallest diameter to filter out the malicious gradients. Similar to MDAM, FLDetector utilizes historical information to predict gradient updates and identifies malicious clients by assessing discrepancies from the actual values.

In the paper, we design an optimization-based attack framework to break all these SOTA poisoning defenses.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we study poisoning attacks to federated learning and aim to break state-of-the-art poisoning defenses that use robust robust aggregators. To this end, we propose an optimization-based attack framework, under which we design customized attacks by uncovering the vulnerabilities of these robust aggregators. Our attacks are extensively evaluated on various threat models and benchmark datasets. The experimental results validate our attacks can break all these robust aggregators and deliver significantly stronger attack performance that the SOTA attacks. Potential future works include designing effective (provable) defenses, generalizing the proposed attack framework on federated learning to other application domains, e.g., graph dataÂ [40], and generalizing the attack to SOTA defenses for privacyÂ [30, 3, 25].
